channel.title: Telephone Network on 0x000216
channel.description: Recent content in Telephone Network on 0x000216

item.title: IP Exchange - The Final Piece For VoIP
item.description: The shift from circuit-switched to packet-switched telephone networks is undeniable. While large companies have adopted enterprise VoIP to enhance efficiency, cut expenses, and prepare for the future, small and medium businesses are considering SIP trunking for bundled high-quality telephone and broadband services. Consumers are switching to cable broadband-telephone packages or third-party VoIP options. However, the PSTN remains. Currently, VoIP systems and services operate in isolation. On-net calls, meaning calls within the same service regardless of location, are often free.

item.title: Signaling for Call Centers
item.description: Every phone call involves two parts: the conversation itself and the signaling that manages the phone network. While signaling might seem purely technical, its implementation significantly impacts call center efficiency. Traditional analog phone lines use the same copper wires, called the local loop, for both voice and signaling. Touchtone dialing, handset lifting, and ringing all rely on electrical signals sent over this shared connection. This method, known as in-band signaling, has limitations.
